item.title: Dealmaker: PE Pins Hopes on Cluster of Software IPOs
item.description:
Dealmaker
As I wrote earlier today, private equity firms are sitting on a backlog of software companies they bought during the buyout frenzy of 2021 and 2022 that they hope to take public or sell.  One reason they can’t cash out is that the initial public offering market has not been receptive to new PE-backed software listings. The value of all PE-backed software companies totaled just $17 billion from 2022 to 2024, less than one-fifth of the deals in 2021, according to PitchBook.  That lukewarm appetite may extend into this year, thanks to the distraction of the planned  blockbuster IPO of SpaceX and expectations that OpenAI, Anthropic and Databricks could follow.
Jan 27, 2026

Dealmaker
By Valida Pau

Welcome back!

As I wrote earlier today, private equity firms are sitting on a backlog of software companies they bought during the buyout frenzy of 2021 and 2022 that they hope to take public or sell. 

One reason they can’t cash out is that the initial public offering market has not been receptive to new PE-backed software listings. The value of all PE-backed software companies totaled just $17 billion from 2022 to 2024, less than one-fifth of the deals in 2021, according to PitchBook. 

That lukewarm appetite may extend into this year, thanks to the distraction of the planned  blockbuster IPO of SpaceX and expectations that OpenAI, Anthropic and Databricks could follow.

“Generally speaking, I think the environment for PE-backed IPOs is going to be more difficult than [that for] VC-backed ones, with the exception of certain vertical software and security companies,” said Jonathan Cofsky, a technology portfolio manager at mutual fund manager Janus Henderson. 

One of the reasons PE-owned software listings are getting little interest is that investors fancy high-growth stories rather than PE-backed companies, which are often older with slower growth rates, say investors in IPOs and investment bankers that underwrite new listings. Plus, investors are worried these companies won’t be able to adapt to AI quickly. 

Companies that were taken private a few years ago would be returning to the public market after massive sell-offs of software-related stocks, driven by the fear that AI tools and applications would replace demand for the enterprise software companies’ products. 

“That was just a very different time for software when the growth rates were much higher and the investors were willing to pay a lot more for software. Most importantly, generative AI wasn’t a thing,” Cofsky said. “It’s not that PE had the wrong thesis, it’s just the world changed.” 

And the few that went public have met with a chilly reception. Shares of Thoma Bravo–backed SailPoint Technologies, the only PE-backed software IPO last year, have fallen 20% since its listing in February. 

The successful IPO of Medline last December gave PE investors hope that listings outside generic corporate software would succeed. The medical supply firm owned by Blackstone raised $6 billion, the most money raised in any offering last year, and the stock has soared more than 50% since its debut.

Possible IPO contenders this year among PE-backed companies include Liftoff, a mobile app ​marketing company owned by Blackstone, which filed IPO paperwork publicly two weeks ago. Genesys, a customer experience software maker backed by Permira and Hellman & Friedman, which delayed a listing last year, could eye an IPO in the coming months as well, according to a person familiar with the discussion. 

Thoma Bravo has explored in recent months taking at least two of its cybersecurity companies this year—Ping Identity and Proofpoint—public this year, according to people with knowledge of the matter. 

How these PE-backed companies perform in the public market will likely determine whether PE firms can manage to chip away at a bigger chunk of their private holdings. 

If they are looking for lessons from last year, they would lower their price expectations. Over two-thirds of 2025 tech IPOs trade below their listing price. Some investors in those small and midsize deals blame the weak performance on companies and their bankers for pricing the stocks too high.

David Levy of Porch Capital speaks about Nvidia’s deepening ties to CoreWeave and the future of edge inference.

item.title: AI Agenda: OpenAI One-Ups Anthropic with New Whistleblower Policy
item.description:
AI Agenda
OpenAI recently updated its policy for handling whistleblower complaints, responding to complaints about AI startups ignoring what are standard rules applying to all companies. It follows similar steps from Anthropic and could pressure other AI companies to follow suit. ͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­
Jan 27, 2026

AI Agenda
By Rocket Drew
Supported by

Thank you for reading the AI Agenda Newsletter! I’d love your feedback, ideas and tips: stephanie@theinformation.com.

If you think someone else might enjoy this newsletter, please pass it forward or they can sign up here.

Hello! Rocket here.

OpenAI recently updated its policy for handling whistleblower complaints, following concerns about AI startups ignoring what are standard rules applying to all companies. It follows similar steps from Anthropic and could pressure other AI companies to follow suit. 

Federal government rules mandate that companies cannot retaliate against employees who report wrongdoing. Legislation governing AI, including the E.U. AI Act and California’s SB 53, has specifically mandated the protections for AI firms. But OpenAI, Anthropic and other AI companies have lobbied against laws containing whistleblower protections, arguing that they could expose trade secrets. OpenAI landed in hot water in May 2024 for an under-the-radar policy that required departing employees to sign non-disparagement agreements to keep their vested equity. (Whistleblowers even asked the Securities Exchange Commission to investigate, but that policy has since been removed.) 

A year ago, the AI Whistleblowing Initiative was founded in Berlin to research and advocate for whistleblower protections at AI companies and to support individual whistleblowers. While some companies were supportive, the initial reaction to its efforts wasn’t entirely friendly. When AIWI ran a campaign last year asking AI companies to publish their whistleblowing policies, one unnamed company sent the organization a cease-and-desist letter.

Karl Koch, founder of the AI Whistleblowing Initiative, said he met with an executive at OpenAI earlier this month to discuss AIWI’s recommendations for improving the previous version of OpenAI’s policy, which was published in 2024. AIWI is releasing the report containing those recommendations Tuesday, along with its initial reactions to OpenAI’s updated policy, Koch said. 

Of the 13 recommendations AIWI made, OpenAI partially or fully addressed eight of them. For instance, the new policy clarifies that OpenAI’s compliance team is in charge of handling these reports. It also lays out protections for employees in particular countries, and even links to the California Attorney General’s whistleblowing hotline.

However, Koch cautioned that there are still many unanswered questions about OpenAI’s internal reporting channels, including how the board of directors and lawyers are involved in handling complaints, and whether the policy is legally binding. 

Still, Koch says OpenAI’s new policy is the strongest whistleblowing policy that any of the leading AI companies have published. It goes further than Anthropic’s, which was published in December. Anthropic’s version is narrowly focused on employees reporting violations of its own safety and security policy and lacks a timeline when it pledges to respond to complaints. 

A spokesperson for Anthropic said in a statement that the company has a non-retaliation policy similar to OpenAI’s that covers additional topics, such as fraud and conflicts of interest, including an anonymous reporting line. Anthropic has also said employees do not have to sign non-disparagement agreements that would make it difficult for them to publicly raise safety concerns.

For any employees that are considering raising concerns, Koch recommends starting by talking to a lawyer, who can review other relevant documents, such as an employee handbook. Employees can also anonymously contact AIWI, which can put them in contact with lawyers that work on whistleblowing cases pro bono.

Here’s what else is going on…

Dario’s Revision Quest

Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei published an essay Monday outlining how he sees the risks from powerful AI, such as the possibility of AI taking over the world or empowering an authoritarian regime. While he ventured into some fresh territory, such as arguing that AI companies themselves could pose authoritarian risks, he mostly pieced together ideas that would be familiar to Anthropic-ologists. 

The bigger surprises came after the essay was published. First, Amodei posted on X that “given the horror we’re seeing in Minnesota, its emphasis on the importance of preserving democratic values and rights at home is particularly relevant.” That statement made Amodei one of the highest-profile tech executives to weigh in on the Minneapolis killing.

The second surprise was that Claude was not responsible for its word count, which exceeded 21,000 words, though it was drafted in only three days. While Claude assisted Amodei with editing and research, Amodei has said that he himself handled the writing. Then again, if I had an editor that could read up to 2 million tokens per minute, I would probably end up writing 21,000-word articles too.

Deals and Debuts

See The Information’s Generative AI Database for an exclusive list of private companies and their investors.

SoftBank halted talks to acquire Switch, a U.S.-based data center operator, for around $50 billion, Bloomberg reported. Both sides are still negotiating a potential investment or partnership, according to the report.

StepFun, which develops large language models and has partnered with smartphone brands, raised over $700 million in a Series B funding round.

Ricursive Technologies, a Palo Alto, Calif.-based AI lab building AI that can improve chip designs, raised $300 million in Series A funding at a $4 billion valuation led by Lightspeed Venture Partners.

DeepWay, which develops self-driving technology for trucking, raised $173 million ahead of an IPO from investors including ABC Impact, Lenovo Capital, Puhua Capital and Sunwoda Electronic Co., Bloomberg reported.

Tandem, which uses AI to automate pharmacy paperwork, is raising $100 million at a $1 billion valuation in a funding round led by Accel, Bloomberg reported.

Zocks, which provides AI for financial advisors, raised $45 million in a Series B funding round led by Lightspeed Venture Partners and QED Investors.

Flora, an AI-powered design app, raised $42 million in Series A funding led by Redpoint Ventures.

Pace, an agentic insurance startup, raised $10 million in Series A funding led by Sequoia Capital.

SpotDraft, which develops on-device contract review tech for regulated legal workflows, raised $8 million in Series B funding from Qualcomm Ventures.

Midship, a San Francisco-based startup that builds AI for accounting fraud testing, raised $4.2 million in seed funding led by Costanoa Ventures.

The European Union has opened a formal investigation into Elon Musk’s X over how the social media service has integrated xAI’s Grok AI chatbot. The investigation comes amid an outcry after users were able to prompt Grok to generate sexualized images of real people on X, including minors.

Microsoft announced the Maia 200, its latest chip designed for running AI models. The company said the chips are already running OpenAI’s GPT-5.2 models.

The U.S. Department of Transportation intends to use Gemini to draft new regulations, and has already used it to draft an unpublished rule for the Federal Aviation Administration, ProPublica reported.

Qwen released Qwen3-Max-Thinking, its latest reasoning model. According to test results that Qwen released, the model is comparable to leading models from OpenAI, Anthropic and Google.

Moonshot AI released a new open-source model, Kimi K2.5, which understands text, image and video.

Anthropic announced new features that will allow users to call up interactive apps like Slack, Canva and Figma within its Claude chatbot.

OpenAI released a report documenting how ChatGPT is being used in scientific research. According to the report, 1.3 million users per week ask ChatGPT about math and science.

A message from ServiceNow

Now your people can AI like they were meant to AI.

Introducing the AI Experience by ServiceNow. Most AI is stuck in silos. Trapped in apps. Disconnected from how people actually work. The AI Experience by ServiceNow® works the way people do. It brings text, voice, images, and agents into a single, seamless interface where AI is the new UI. Learn more

item.title: My AI Had Already Fixed the Code Before I Saw It
item.description:
Compounding engineering turns every pull request, bug fix, and code review into permanent lessons your development tools apply automatically  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Source Code

My AI Had Already Fixed the Code Before I Saw It

Compounding engineering turns every pull request, bug fix, and code review into permanent lessons your development tools apply automatically

by Kieran Klaassen

While we’re on our Think Week offsite this week, we’re resurfacing Cora general manager Kieran Klaassen’s work on the theme of compound engineering. In this piece, Kieran lays out his definition of the term and the shift it represents: What if your AI tools learned—and autonomously applied those lessons to future work? That’s what happened when his Claude Code agent incorporated three months of prior feedback without being asked. The future of development is self-improving systems, not just faster coding.—Kate Lee

Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up to get it in your inbox.

Before I opened my laptop, the code had reviewed itself.

I launched GitHub expecting to dive into my usual routine—flag poorly named ﻿variables﻿, trim excessive tests, and suggest simpler ways to handle errors. Instead, I found a few strong comments from Claude Code, the AI that writes and edits in my terminal:

“Changed variable naming to match pattern from PR [pull request] #234, removed excessive test coverage per feedback on PR #219, added error handling similar to approved approach in PR #241.”

In other words, Claude had learned from three prior months of code reviews and applied those lessons without being asked. It had picked up my tastes thoroughly, the way a sharp new teammate would—and with receipts.

It felt like cheating, but it wasn’t—it was compounding. Every time we fix something, the system learns. Every time we review something, the system learns. Every time we fail in an avoidable way, the system learns. That’s how we build Cora, Every’s AI-enabled email assistant, now: Create systems that create systems, then get out of the way.

I call this compounding engineering: building self-improving development systems where each iteration makes the next one faster, safer, and better.

Typical AI engineering is about short-term gains. You prompt, it codes, you ship. Then you start over. Compounding engineering is about building systems with memory, where every pull request teaches the system, every bug becomes a permanent lesson, and every code review updates the defaults. AI engineering makes you faster today. Compounding engineering makes you faster tomorrow, and each day after.

Three months of compounding engineering on Cora have completely changed the way I think about code. I can’t write a function anymore without thinking about whether I’m teaching the system or just solving today’s problem. Every bug fix feels half-done if it doesn’t prevent its entire category going forward, and code reviews without extractable lessons seem like wasted time.

When you’re done reading this, you’ll have the same affliction.

Write at the speed of thought

That gap between your brain and your fingers kills momentum. Monologue lets you speak naturally and get perfect text 3x faster, and your tone, vocabulary, and style is kept intact. It auto-learns proper nouns, handles multilingual code-switching mid-sentence, and edits for accuracy. Free 1,000 words to start.

Download Monologue for Mac
Want to sponsor Every? Click here.

The 10-minute investment that pays dividends forever

Compounding engineering asks for an upfront investment: You have to teach your tools before they can teach themselves.

Here’s an example of how this works in practice: I’m building a “frustration detector” for Cora; the goal is for our AI assistant to notice when users get annoyed with the app’s behavior and automatically file improvement reports. A traditional approach would be to write the detector, test it manually, tweak, and repeat. This takes significant expertise and time, a lot of which is spent context-switching between thinking like a user and thinking like a developer. It’d be better if the system could teach itself.

So I start with a sample conversation where I express frustration—like repeatedly asking the same question with increasingly terse language. Then I hand it off to Claude with a simple prompt: “This conversation shows frustration. Write a test that checks if our tool catches it.”

Claude writes the test. The test fails—the natural first step in test-driven development (TDD). Next, I tell Claude to write the actual detection logic. Once written, it still doesn’t work perfectly, which is also to be expected. Now here’s the beautiful part: I can tell Claude to iterate on the frustration detection prompt until the test passes.

Not only that—it can keep iterating. Claude adjusts the prompt and runs the test again. It reads the logs, sees why it missed a frustration signal, and adjusts again. After a few rounds, the test passes.

But AI outputs aren’t deterministic—a prompt that works once might fail the next time.

So I have Claude run the test 10 times. When it only identifies frustration in four out of 10 passes, Claude analyzes why it failed the other six times. It studies the chain of thought (the step-by-step thinking Claude showed when deciding whether someone was frustrated) from each failed run and discovers a pattern: It’s missing hedged language a user might use, like, “Hmm, not quite,” which actually signals frustration when paired with repeated requests. Claude then updates the original frustration-detection prompt to specifically look for this polite-but-frustrated language.

On the next iteration, it’s able to identify a frustrated user nine times out of 10. Good enough to ship.

We codify this entire workflow—from identifying frustration patterns to iterating prompts to validation—in CLAUDE.md, the special file Claude pulls in for context before each conversation. The next time we need to detect a user’s emotion or behavior, we don’t start from scratch. We say: “Use the prompt workflow from the frustration detector.” The system already knows what to do.

And unlike human-written code, the “implementation” here is a prompt that Claude can endlessly refine based on test results. Every failure teaches the system. Every success becomes a pattern. (We’re planning to open-source this prompt testing framework so other teams can build their own compounding workflows.)

From terminal to mission control

Most engineers treat AI as an extra set of hands. Compounding engineering turns it into an entire team that gets faster, sharper, and more aligned with every task.

At Cora, we’ve used this approach to:

  1. Transform production errors into permanent fixes by having AI agents automatically investigate crashes, reproduce problems from system logs, and generate both the solution and tests to prevent it from happening again. This turns every failure into a one-time event.
  2. Extract architectural decisions from collaborative work sessions by recording design discussions with teammates, then having Claude document why certain approaches were chosen—creating consistent standards that new team members inherit on day one.
  3. Build review agents with different expertise by capturing my own preferences in a “Kieran reviewer” that enforces my style choices, then adding specialized perspectives like a “Rails expert reviewer” for framework best practices or a “performance reviewer” for speed optimization.
  4. Automate visual documentation by deploying an agent that automatically detects interface changes, captures before/after screenshots across different screen sizes and themes, and generates comprehensive visual documentation—eliminating a 30-minute manual task while ensuring every interface change is properly documented for reviewers.
  5. Parallelize feedback resolution by creating a dedicated agent for each piece of reviewer feedback that works simultaneously to address concerns. This compresses a back-and-forth process that could take hours into parallel work where 10 issues get resolved in the time it used to take for one.

This way of working signifies a shift in what it means to be an engineer. Your job isn’t to type code anymore, but to design the systems that design the systems. It’s the only approach I’ve found where today’s work makes tomorrow’s work exponentially easier, and where every improvement you make is permanent.

In the three months that we’ve been running a compounding engineering workflow on Cora, our metrics have shifted noticeably. We’ve seen time-to-ship on features drop from over a week to 1-3 days on average, and bugs caught before production have increased substantially. Pull request review cycles that used to drag on for days now finish in hours.

The compounding engineering playbook

Building systems that learn requires rewiring how you think about development. Even if you’re sold on compounding engineering, you might be wondering how to start. After months of refinement—and plenty of failed experiments—I’ve distilled it to five steps.

Step 1: Teach through work

Every time you make a decision, capture it and codify it to stop the AI from making the same mistake again. CLAUDE.md becomes your taste in plain language—why you prefer guard clauses over nested ifs or name things a certain way. Keep it short, keep it alive.

Likewise, the llms.txt file stores your high-level architectural decisions—the design principles and system-wide rules that don’t change when you restructure individual features.

These files turn your preferences into permanent system knowledge that Claude applies automatically.


Step 2: Turn failures into upgrades

Something breaks? Good. That’s data. But here’s where most engineers stop: They fix the immediate issue and move on. Compounding engineers add the test, update the rule, and write the evaluation.

Take a recent example from Cora: A user reported that they never received their daily email Brief—a critical failure! We wrote tests that catch similar delivery lapses, updated our monitoring rules to flag when Briefs aren’t sent, and built evaluations that continuously verify the delivery pipeline.

Now the system always watches for this category of problem. What started as a failure has made our tools permanently smarter.

Step 3: Orchestrate in parallel

Unlike hiring engineers at $150,000 each, AI workers scale on demand. The only limits are your orchestration skills and compute costs—not headcount, hiring timelines, or team coordination overhead. You can spin up five specialized agents for the cost of a cup of coffee.

My monitor now looks like mission control:

  1. Left lane: Planning. A Claude instance reads issues, researches approaches, and writes detailed implementation plans.
  2. Middle lane: Delegating. Another Claude takes those plans and writes code, creates tests, and implements features.
  3. Right lane: Reviewing. A third Claude reviews the output against CLAUDE.md, suggests improvements, and catches issues.

It feels awkward at first—like juggling while learning to juggle—but within a week it becomes natural.


Step 4: Keep context lean but yours

The internet is full of “ultimate CLAUDE.md files” you can copy. Don’t. Your context should reflect your codebase, your patterns, and your hard-won lessons. Ten specific rules you follow beat 100 generic ones. And when rules stop serving you, delete them. Living context means pruning as much as growing.

When I review my CLAUDE.md/slash command and agent files, it feels like reading my own software philosophy—a reflection of what I’ve learned, what I value, and how I think code should be built. If it doesn’t resonate with you personally, it won’t guide the AI effectively.

Step 5: Trust the process, verify output

This is the hardest step. Your instinct will be to micromanage and review every line. Instead, trust the system you’ve built—but verify through tests, evals, and spot checks. It’s like learning to be a CEO or a movie director: You can’t do everything yourself, but you can build systems that catch problems before they escalate. When something comes back wrong (and it will), teach the system why it was wrong. Next time, it won’t be.

Stop coding, start compounding

Here’s what I know: Companies are paying $400 per month for what used to cost $400,000 per year. One-person startups are competing with funded teams. AI is democratizing not just coding, but entire engineering systems. And leverage is shifting to those who teach these systems faster than they type.

Start with one experiment log today. When something fails that shouldn’t have, invest the time to prevent it from happening again—build the test, write the rule, and capture the lesson. Open three terminals. Try the three-lane setup: Plan in one, build in another, and review in a third. Say “pull request” and watch the branches bloom.

Then do it again tomorrow, and see what compounds.

Thanks to Katie Parrott for editorial support.

Kieran Klaassen is the general manager of Cora, Every’s email product. Follow him on X at @kieranklaassen or on LinkedIn.

To read more essays like this, subscribe to Every, and follow us on X at @every and on LinkedIn.

  • • The startup secured $42 million in Series A funding led by Redpoint Ventures, with participation from notable investors including Vercel CEO Guillermo Rauch, Twitch founder Justin Kan, and a16z Games. Total funding now stands at $52 million.
  • • Flora plans to scale enterprise sales, enhance creative controls, and integrate traditional editing features, aiming to broaden its impact across industries like advertising, fashion, and branding while doubling or tripling its workforce by year-end.

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 27, 2026
Google AI Overviews cite YouTube more than any medical site for health queries
• Article: https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2026/jan/24/google-ai-overviews-youtube-medical-citations-study
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46766031
• Score: 392
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic**: The discussion centers around Google’s AI system, Gemini, and its tendency to cite YouTube videos, including AI-generated content, as sources for its responses, particularly for health-related queries. Commenters debate the reliability and impact of this practice.
  • 2. **Key Themes**:
  • • **AI-generated content concerns**: Many commenters express distrust in AI-generated videos used as sources, citing their potential to spread misinformation and debase shared reality. The "closed loop" of AI citing AI content is viewed as problematic.
  • • **YouTube as a source**: Commenters are divided on whether citing YouTube is inherently bad. Some argue that it hosts valuable content from credible sources like hospitals and licensed professionals, while others criticize its lack of editorial oversight and prevalence of misinformation.
  • • **Reliability of AI responses**: Several commenters note inaccuracies and misleading information in Gemini’s responses, with some highlighting issues like vague citations and fabricated claims.
  • • **Health advice concerns**: There is skepticism about AI systems providing health-related advice, with concerns about the lack of tailored information and the prevalence of dubious recommendations from non-credible sources.
  • • **Corporate priorities**: Many commenters believe Google prioritizes engagement and ad revenue over the quality and reliability of its AI systems, citing conflicts of interest in favoring YouTube content.
  • 3. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • **Agreement**: Most commenters agree that AI systems should prioritize trustworthy, grounded sources and avoid reliance on AI-generated videos. There is widespread concern about the implications of misinformation and the degradation of shared reality.
  • • **Disagreement**: Some argue that YouTube can be a valid source if the videos are from credible organizations, while others believe YouTube’s general-purpose nature makes it unsuitable for medical or factual citations.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • • The overall sentiment is critical of Gemini and Google’s approach, with frustration over the perceived decline in quality and trustworthiness of AI systems. Some commenters express pessimism about the future of AI reliability, while others share nuanced perspectives on its potential benefits when used carefully.
  • 5. **Notable Insights**:
  • • A few commenters suggest alternative tools like Kagi’s Research agent or specific platforms that anchor on peer-reviewed papers for better reliability.
  • • Personal anecdotes highlight both positive and negative experiences with AI systems in health contexts, showcasing their potential utility but also their risks.
  • • Commenters emphasize the need for rigorous source verification and transparency in AI-generated responses to mitigate misinformation.
  • • The concept of "citogenesis," where uncritical citation creates feedback loops of misinformation, is mentioned as a broader issue in AI systems.
  • 6. **Unique Contributions**:
  • • A commenter shares a surprising instance where GPT3 provided accurate medical predictions, contrasting with Gemini’s perceived shortcomings.
  • • Others highlight systemic issues like the commercialization of search results and the lack of free access to high-quality medical journals, which may drive AI systems toward less reliable sources.
There is an AI code review bubble
• Article: https://www.greptile.com/blog/ai-code-review-bubble
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46766961
• Score: 301
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • The growing competition in AI code review tools highlights the importance of differentiation. Greptile emphasizes independence, refusing to integrate code generation features to ensure unbiased validation, likening it to separating auditors from bookkeepers.
  • • Greptile envisions a future of fully autonomous code validation, focusing on automating review, testing, and QA tasks to minimize human involvement. Unlike competitors, it avoids building user interfaces, positioning itself as a background automation solution.
  • • Feedback loops are central to Greptile’s approach, enabling iterative refinement between coding agents and validation agents until code meets high standards. Its Claude Code plugin exemplifies this by automating responses to review comments for seamless collaboration.

Discussion Highlights:

  • • **Main Topic:** The discussion centers around the effectiveness and challenges of AI tools for code review, including their strengths, weaknesses, and potential impact on software development workflows.
  • • **Signal-to-Noise Ratio:** A recurring theme is the poor signal-to-noise ratio in AI code review tools. Many commenters note that while AI tools often catch critical bugs, they also generate a large volume of irrelevant or low-value comments, which can overwhelm developers and lead to fatigue or dismissal of the feedback.
  • • **Comparison to Human Review:** Commenters generally agree that AI tools are not a replacement for human reviewers but can serve as useful complements. Human reviewers are better at understanding broader architectural and business contexts, mentoring team members, and making nuanced decisions about what is important. AI tools, on the other hand, excel at catching repetitive or low-level issues that humans might overlook.
  • • **Tool-Specific Experiences:**
  • • Tools like Copilot, Bugbot, and Claude Code received mixed reviews, with some users praising their ability to catch subtle bugs or suggest improvements, while others criticized their verbosity and lack of contextual understanding.
  • • Greptile was mentioned frequently, with some users finding it too noisy and prone to irrelevant suggestions, while others noted its potential to improve with better configuration or prompting.
  • • Coderabbit, Cursor, and Unblocked were highlighted as providing more focused and useful feedback compared to others.
  • • **Integration and Workflow:** Several commenters emphasized the importance of integrating AI tools seamlessly into existing workflows. Tools that are bundled with platforms like GitHub or GitLab were seen as having an advantage due to ease of use and lower integration costs. Some commenters expressed skepticism about the long-term viability of standalone AI code review tools, predicting that major platforms will eventually dominate this space.
  • • **Unique Insights:**
  • • Some commenters suggested that AI tools should focus on presenting fewer but higher-quality comments, potentially ranked by severity or importance, to reduce noise and improve developer experience.
  • • A few noted that AI tools could help with tasks like identifying race conditions, dead code, or overlooked edge cases, but their effectiveness diminishes for high-level design or business logic issues.
  • • There was discussion about the potential for AI tools to be misused or to create over-engineered code if developers blindly follow their suggestions.
  • • **Sentiment:** The overall sentiment of the discussion is mixed. While there is recognition of the potential value of AI code review tools, many commenters are critical of their current limitations, particularly around noise, lack of contextual understanding, and the risk of over-reliance on AI.
  • • **Broader Implications:** Commenters debated the future of AI code review, with some predicting that as AI improves, it could handle more aspects of the review process autonomously. Others expressed concerns about the potential loss of human understanding and the cultural aspects of code review, such as knowledge sharing and mentorship.
  • • **Critical Voices:** Some commenters questioned the fundamental premise of AI code review, arguing that it might be redundant or counterproductive when paired with AI-generated code. Others expressed frustration with the marketing and over-promising of certain tools, describing the current state of AI code review as part of a broader "AI bubble.
  • • **Conclusion:** While AI tools for code review are seen as promising, their current limitations, particularly in filtering out noise and understanding context, prevent them from fully replacing human reviewers. They are most effective when used as complementary tools to enhance, rather than replace, human judgment.
Porting 100k lines from TypeScript to Rust using Claude Code in a month
• Article: https://blog.vjeux.com/2026/analysis/porting-100k-lines-from-typescript-to-rust-using-claude-code-in-a-month.html
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46765694
• Score: 232
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • A developer successfully ported 100,000 lines of JavaScript code from the Pokémon Showdown project to Rust using Claude Code, an AI coding assistant, over four weeks, achieving a faster and more efficient implementation.
  • • The process required significant manual oversight, including sandbox workarounds, error resolution, and iterative cleanup, showcasing the potential and current limitations of AI-driven coding tools.
  • • Despite no prior Rust experience, the project resulted in a functional, optimized Rust codebase with 5,000 commits, highlighting the transformative potential of AI in software development while emphasizing the need for human expertise.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic**: The discussion revolves around the challenges and experiences of using AI tools, particularly Claude, to port code between programming languages, with a focus on Rust, JavaScript, and other environments. The broader theme includes the effectiveness, limitations, and quirks of AI in software engineering tasks.
  • 2. **Challenges with AI Porting**:
  • • Many commenters shared frustrations with Claude's tendency to introduce bugs or make unnecessary "improvements" during code porting, often leading to wasted time debugging issues.
  • • There were mentions of duplication and non-idiomatic code being generated, especially in Rust, which caused integration issues.
  • • Some commenters noted that AI often struggles with tasks requiring deep understanding of the original code's constraints, resulting in suboptimal or broken outputs.
  • 3. **Strategies and Insights**:
  • • Several participants suggested porting tests first and using them as a contract to ensure functionality during the porting process. Modular and progressive testing was highlighted as a key approach.
  • • File-by-file or class-by-class porting was recommended to maintain structure and avoid introducing unnecessary complexity.
  • • Using negative examples in prompts or leveraging plugins like code-review tools was proposed as a way to improve AI adherence to instructions.
  • 4. **Sentiment and Opinions**:
  • • Mixed sentiment was evident. While some commenters appreciated the productivity gains and experimental nature of AI-driven porting, others were critical of the quality of the results and the significant babysitting required.
  • • Skepticism was expressed regarding the trustworthiness of AI-generated code, especially for critical or production-grade projects.
  • • A few comments outright dismissed certain projects as incomplete or disingenuous, questioning the utility of AI-generated codebases that merely compile without proper validation.
  • 5. **Unique Contributions**:
  • • Anecdotes of AI being used to port large codebases, such as a closed-source web conferencing tool or a low-level JS library, demonstrated potential use cases but also highlighted the need for human oversight.
  • • Some commenters discussed the broader implications of AI tools in software development, such as using AI to port Python libraries to GIL-free versions or benchmarking ports across multiple languages.
  • • A humorous aside involved using AppleScript to auto-approve Claude's prompts, showcasing creative workarounds for AI quirks.
  • 6. **Cost and Usage Concerns**:
  • • The cost of running AI tools like Claude continuously was debated, with commenters sharing experiences about token limits and opaque subscription usage caps. API costs were noted as potentially higher than subscription models for heavy usage.
  • 7. **General Takeaways**:
  • • AI tools like Claude show promise in automating tedious tasks like code porting but are far from perfect and require significant human intervention to ensure quality.
  • • The discussion highlighted the importance of robust testing, clear prompts, and understanding the limitations of AI when integrating it into software development workflows.
  • • While some commenters were optimistic about future advancements, others remained skeptical about AI's current capabilities, especially for complex or large-scale projects.
When AI 'builds a browser,' check the repo before believing the hype
• Article: https://www.theregister.com/2026/01/26/cursor_opinion/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46769965
• Score: 225
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Cursor claimed to have built a web browser using GPT-5.2, boasting 3 million lines of AI-generated code and a "from-scratch" Rust rendering engine, but the project was far from functional, with major compilation errors and reliance on existing tools like Servo and QuickJS.
  • • Developers found the browser's performance abysmal, with slow page loads and poorly designed code, leading to criticism from experts who described it as "spaghetti" and unsuitable for real-world use.
  • • The incident highlights the dangers of AI hype, as the experiment was marketed as a milestone rather than an internal learning exercise, emphasizing the need for validation and practical benchmarks over exaggerated claims.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • The discussion centered around the experiment of using AI to build a browser, which resulted in a codebase of over 3 million lines. Commenters debated its implications, effectiveness, and the broader narrative it promotes about AI capabilities.
  • • A recurring theme was skepticism about the value of "lines of code" (LOC) as a productivity metric, with many arguing that high LOC often indicates inefficiency or technical debt rather than progress.
  • • The hype surrounding AI's ability to produce complex software autonomously was critiqued, with commenters emphasizing the gap between AI demos and real-world production quality.
  • • Some commenters discussed the broader implications of AI's role in software development, including its impact on management decisions and developer productivity.
  • 2. **Agreements**:
  • • Many commenters agreed that presenting the browser project as a success was misleading, as the resulting codebase was far from functional and relied heavily on external dependencies.
  • • There was consensus that LOC is a flawed metric for measuring software quality or developer productivity, with several commenters citing historical criticism of this approach.
  • • Commenters broadly acknowledged that AI tools can be useful for specific tasks, such as autocomplete or refactoring, but are not yet capable of handling complex projects without significant human intervention.
  • 3. **Disagreements**:
  • • While some viewed the experiment as a failure and a marketing stunt, others argued it demonstrated notable progress in AI's ability to tackle long, complex tasks, even if the outcome was imperfect.
  • • A few commenters defended AI coding tools as transformative for productivity in certain contexts, contrasting with the prevailing sentiment that the browser experiment was overhyped.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • • The overall sentiment was critical, with many commenters expressing frustration at the marketing and hype surrounding the project. There was concern about the unrealistic expectations being set for AI in software development.
  • • Some commenters expressed cautious optimism about the future potential of AI, emphasizing that the experiment highlights progress despite its shortcomings.
  • 5. **Unique Insights**:
  • • The analogy of "app-shaped objects" was used to describe AI-generated projects that superficially resemble functional software but fail under real-world conditions.
  • • A commenter highlighted the economic consequences of AI hype, suggesting it leads to misguided management decisions and investor behavior.
  • • The concept of entropy in software development was discussed, with AI seen as contributing to technical debt rather than reducing it.
  • • Some commenters proposed iterative approaches for AI-driven projects, starting with simpler tasks and gradually increasing complexity.
  • 6. **Key Takeaways**:
  • • The browser experiment showcased AI's ability to generate large amounts of code but failed to deliver a functional product, leading to skepticism about its practical value.
  • • Unrealistic claims about AI capabilities risk undermining trust and setting developers up for disappointment.
  • • AI tools are valuable for constrained tasks but are not yet capable of replacing human expertise in complex software projects.
  • • The hype cycle around AI continues to influence management and investment decisions, often to the detriment of developers and the industry at large.
Show HN: Only 1 LLM can fly a drone
• Article: https://github.com/kxzk/snapbench
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46764170
• Score: 169
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • A simulation inspired by Pokémon Snap tested 7 large language models (LLMs) on piloting a drone to identify creatures in a 3D voxel world. Surprisingly, the cheapest model, Gemini Flash, outperformed more expensive and advanced counterparts by successfully adjusting altitude to identify targets.
  • • The experiment revealed that spatial reasoning and instruction-following don’t necessarily scale with model size. Smaller models like Gemini Flash may excel due to different training data or simpler, more literal execution of commands.
  • • Future possibilities include model-specific tuning, richer feedback systems, extended iterations, and real-world drone benchmarks, potentially paving the way for more effective AI-driven navigation in physical and virtual spaces.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic and Context**:
  • • The discussion revolves around the use of large language models (LLMs) for piloting drones and reasoning in 3D spaces. Commenters debated the feasibility, effectiveness, and limitations of using LLMs for tasks that involve spatial reasoning and real-time control.
  • 2. **Key Points of Discussion**:
  • • **LLM Capabilities and Limitations**:
  • • Gemini 3 was highlighted as a model with some spatial reasoning abilities, though it is still unreliable for tasks like determining orientation (e.g., left vs. right). Other models like Qwen3VL were noted for their spatial grounding in pixel space but lacked reasoning capabilities.
  • • Several commenters pointed out that LLMs are not inherently designed for tasks like drone navigation or spatial reasoning, as they are primarily trained on text data. However, their ability to reason and generate commands makes them useful in specific contexts.
  • • **Challenges with Current Approaches**:
  • • Many commenters emphasized the brittleness of using a detection prepass followed by reasoning in text. This approach can lead to loss of important spatial and temporal data, resulting in errors such as state aliasing or compounded mistakes over time.
  • • LLMs were criticized for their unsuitability for real-time control tasks, with some suggesting traditional control systems (e.g., PID controllers) or gaming engines as better alternatives.
  • • **Use Cases and Applications**:
  • • Some commenters argued for the potential of LLMs in drone-related applications, such as responding to natural language commands, object identification, and autonomous decision-making. Examples included search-and-rescue missions, security drones, or waiter drones in restaurants.
  • • Others mentioned experiments with embodied LLMs and suggested that tighter feedback loops and dedicated training could improve their performance in such tasks.
  • • **Alternative Models and Tools**:
  • • Visual-language action (VLA) models were suggested as better suited for action-based tasks compared to general visual-language models (VLMs). Links to relevant projects like "Cognitive Drone" were shared.
  • • The idea of using LLMs to write programs for drone navigation, rather than directly controlling drones, was proposed as a potentially more effective approach.
  • 3. **Sentiment and Diverging Opinions**:
  • • The sentiment was mixed. While some commenters were optimistic about the potential of LLMs for general reasoning and novel applications, others were skeptical of their practical use for drone control, citing their inherent limitations.
  • • There was a divide between those who saw LLM-based drone control as an exciting hacker project and those who viewed it as impractical or the wrong tool for the job.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • • A commenter highlighted the importance of carrying forward uncertainty and temporal tracking from the vision stage to avoid compounded errors in reasoning.
  • • Another commenter pointed out that LLMs could complement traditional navigation models by handling ambiguous situations where reasoning is required, such as interpreting unexpected events.
  • • A few commenters raised concerns about the ethical implications of LLMs controlling drones, particularly in weaponized scenarios, referencing dystopian themes from popular media.
  • 5. **Conclusion**:
  • • The discussion showcased a blend of technical analysis, practical concerns, and philosophical debates about the role of LLMs in embodied tasks. While LLMs have potential in certain contexts, their current limitations in spatial reasoning and real-time control make them less suitable for direct drone operation without significant augmentation or alternative approaches.
Suspiciously precise floats, or, how I got Claude's real limits
• Article: https://she-llac.com/claude-limits
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46756742
• Score: 59
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • A user discovered that Anthropic's Claude subscription plans unintentionally reveal exact usage limits through unrounded floats in the API, allowing for precise calculations of credit-token formulas and model multipliers.
  • • Using mathematical techniques like the Stern-Brocot tree and lowest common denominator analysis, the researcher uncovered the true usage limits by recovering fractions from floating-point numbers.
  • • This discovery highlights potential side-channel vulnerabilities in systems, as Anthropic's pricing details were inadvertently exposed due to overlooked rounding practices.

Discussion Highlights:

  • • The discussion revolves around methods for analyzing and converting repeating decimals into simpler forms or fractions.
  • • The initial comment by "zahlman" highlights an approach to simplify the repeating decimal 0.16327272727 by multiplying it by 11, resulting in a simpler value (1.796). The commenter appreciates the general analysis method but suggests a simpler approach for this specific case.
  • • A reply by "alyxya" explains a standard method for converting repeating decimals to fractions. They detail the process of dividing the repeating period by a sequence of 9s matching the length of the period, ultimately providing a fraction (449/2750) for the given decimal.
  • • Another reply by "PretzelPirate" asks whether the concept of multiplying by 11 is a named technique, showing interest in learning more about it.
  • • The tone of the discussion is analytical and curious, with commenters sharing methods and seeking additional knowledge. There are no significant disagreements, and the sentiment is constructive and collaborative.
OracleGPT: Thought Experiment on an AI Powered Executive
• Article: https://senteguard.com/blog/#post-7fYcaQrAcfsldmSb7zVM
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46766507
• Score: 57
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • The use of AI and autonomous systems in decision-making roles, including algorithmic trading, autopilot systems, and the hypothetical idea of an "expert system" running a business or government functions.
  • • The feasibility and implications of AI systems being used for governance, such as implementing direct democracy or centralizing decision-making.
  • • Concerns about accountability when AI systems are given autonomy in management or policy-making roles.
  • • Criticism of current AI capabilities, particularly large language models (LLMs), and their limitations in handling complex or high-stakes tasks like legal briefs or policymaking.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement**:
  • • Many commenters agree that AI systems are already being used in critical roles, such as trading and aviation, but question their broader application in management or governance.
  • • There is consensus that accountability is a significant barrier to fully autonomous AI decision-making, as AI cannot be held responsible in the same way humans can.
  • • Several commenters highlight the limitations of current AI systems, particularly LLMs, in reliably producing accurate or trustworthy outputs.
  • 3. **Key Points of Disagreement**:
  • • Some commenters are optimistic about the potential for AI to revolutionize governance (e.g., through direct democracy), while others are skeptical, citing risks of authoritarianism or manipulation by those in power.
  • • The practicality of using AI for management or governance is debated, with some seeing it as inevitable or beneficial and others viewing it as naive or fraught with challenges.
  • • There is disagreement on whether AI systems are more or less accountable than human managers, with some arguing that AI could simplify accountability (e.g., by being easily shut down) and others pointing out the ethical and legal complexities.
  • 4. **Notable Insights**:
  • • A commenter referenced the sci-fi work "Manna" as an example of an AI-run business, sparking debate on its realism and applicability to real-world scenarios.
  • • The idea of decentralized AI governance, where individual citizens control their own AI agents in a direct democracy setup, was proposed as an alternative to centralized systems.
  • • A commenter mentioned an experimental project using historical political debates to train an AI model for capturing divergent views, highlighting potential academic interest in this area.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion reflects a mix of curiosity, skepticism, and cautious optimism. While some commenters are intrigued by the possibilities of AI in management and governance, many express concerns about accountability, ethical risks, and the current limitations of AI technology.
  • 6. **Unique Contributions**:
  • • The suggestion to decentralize AI governance by training individual agents per citizen was a particularly innovative idea.
  • • Historical context and references, such as the "Manna" sci-fi story and a GitHub project on AI and governance, added depth to the discussion.
  • • Humor and satire, such as the suggestion to make AI the CEO of Oracle, lightened the tone in parts of the conversation.
Is OpenAI Dead Yet?
• Article: https://isopenaideadyet.com/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46777448
• Score: 53
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No, not yet. Still alive after 3,703 days... But getting there!

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • • The competitive landscape of AI development, particularly between the US and China, was a central topic. Commenters debated whether US AI models would maintain their lead or if Chinese models could catch up, with some pointing to China's historical ability to innovate and scale in other industries.
  • • OpenAI's current position and future prospects were discussed, with questions about its profitability, competition, and sustainability in a commoditized AI market.
  • • The difficulty of shorting OpenAI or gaining financial exposure to its success or failure was explored, with suggestions ranging from shorting associated companies to using prediction markets.
  • • Skepticism towards media narratives in AI, especially regarding exaggerated claims or negative rhetoric, was highlighted.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement**:
  • • There was general acknowledgment of the competitive pressures in the AI space and the challenges faced by OpenAI and other companies in maintaining leadership.
  • • Some commenters agreed that Chinese companies face similar issues to US companies in scaling and sustaining AI operations.
  • • The media's tendency to sensationalize or misrepresent developments in AI was a shared concern.
  • 3. **Key Points of Disagreement**:
  • • Opinions varied on whether Chinese AI models are genuinely behind US models or if they are closing the gap. Some commenters argued that China has proven its ability to innovate, while others expressed skepticism about its ability to surpass the US.
  • • There was debate over the feasibility and effectiveness of shorting OpenAI-related investments, with some suggesting it is a risky or impractical strategy.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • • One commenter pointed out that OpenAI's potential collapse could impact the share prices of publicly traded companies with ties to AI, such as Microsoft, Oracle, and SoftBank.
  • • The fragmented nature of AI development across different regions (US, China, Europe) was noted as a likely outcome, with each region potentially developing its own models to avoid reliance on foreign technology.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment was mixed, with a blend of cautious optimism about AI's future and skepticism about specific companies' sustainability and the media's portrayal of the industry. While some commenters expressed confidence in the US maintaining its AI lead, others were more critical of assuming long-term dominance.
  • 6. **Notable Contributions**:
  • • A detailed comment highlighted China's historical trajectory in innovation and manufacturing, arguing that dismissing its AI potential could be shortsighted.
  • • Links to external resources, such as prediction markets and investment fund details, added depth to the financial discussion around OpenAI.
  • Overall, the discussion reflected a nuanced and critical examination of AI's competitive dynamics, OpenAI's trajectory, and the broader implications for the industry.
Georgia leads push to ban datacenters used to power America's AI boom
• Article: https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2026/jan/26/georgia-datacenters-ai-ban
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46767696
• Score: 52
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • • The discussion revolves around the regulation and impact of data centers, with a focus on energy consumption, environmental concerns, and local community effects.
  • • One commenter proposed alternative regulations for data centers instead of outright bans, such as requiring zero water usage, zero emissions, limits on noise levels, zoning restrictions, and energy usage caps.
  • • Several commenters debated the rationale behind banning data centers:
  • • One commenter argued that the focus should be on increasing electricity generation capacity rather than banning data centers.
  • • Another highlighted the issue of utilities scaling up power capacity to meet anticipated demand from data centers, only for the data centers to reduce their needs or abandon plans, leaving local ratepayers burdened with the costs.
  • • A commenter shared a personal perspective on living near a data center, describing increased electricity costs, pollution, and a negative impact on quality of life.
  • • Environmental and resource concerns were emphasized:
  • • One commenter noted the rapid proliferation of data centers compared to the slower pace of building power plants, suggesting a mismatch in infrastructure development.
  • • Another humorously criticized the prioritization of data storage over basic needs like clean air and water.
  • • A separate thread briefly touched on AI regulation and its connection to data centers:
  • • One commenter claimed it is federally illegal to regulate AI, but others refuted this, citing the rejection of a proposed moratorium on state AI regulation and clarifying that current discussions focus on data centers and energy, not AI itself.
  • • It was also pointed out that executive orders do not override local land use decisions or moratoriums on data center siting.
  • • Overall, the sentiment of the discussion is mixed, with some commenters advocating for more thoughtful regulation of data centers and others expressing frustration over their local and environmental impacts. The conversation also reflects broader concerns about balancing technological progress with resource management and community well-being.

auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>In 2011, Palantir did something funny. They took their solutions engineers and integration engineers—typically among the lower-status roles in any engineering org—and gave them a new title: </span><em>forward-deployed engineer</em><span>. They even called them “Deltas,” like Delta Force. It sounded ridiculous, and it worked brilliantly.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>It seems like Palantir understood two things. First, they understood that these employees were undervalued: they were critical to customer success and business reputation, but traditionally treated as replaceable help. Second, they understood something about titles, which we’ll call </span><em>title arbitrage</em><span>: the fact that </span><strong>titles can be an effective way of meme-ing into existence the change you want to see in the world.</strong></p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 style="text-decoration: none;">Subscribed</span></a></div></div></div></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;">What is title arbitrage?</h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Title arbitrage means creating new roles to signify new powers that are emerging within the organization, and therefore, new capabilities of the organization itself.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Like it or not, a lot of professional life is judging people by their titles. The CEO is probably the most important person in the room, and the COO, CTO or CFO is probably the second-most (depending on the company). Titles are useful. They tell us something about the work product of the person: the Vice President of Manufacturing is, well, the guy in charge of manufacturing. Titles confer legitimacy.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Titles are also about </span><em>legible organizational capacity</em><span>. Companies are these weird things where many people get together to take actions in coordinated ways that add up to be much more than what any individual person could do. And in order for that coordination to be effective, you need a shared agreement over what roles speak to what organizational capacities.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>But here’s the thing about organizational capacity: it </span><em>changes</em><span>. The world changes, and different skills and competencies become more useful or less useful. In 1770, cavalry officers needed to be able to ride horses; but by 1970, the “cavalry” meant helicopters. So the distribution of power, of </span><em>leverage</em><span>, shifts. And eventually titles, which are supposed to signify power, have to shift with them.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">And the people who figure this out earlier than others, the ones who know where the wind is blowing, can reap enormous benefits.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">By recasting the role, like Walmart did with “Greeter” or Disney with “Imagineer”, Palantir effectively bet: “deep software integrations with huge enterprises and governments will be really important in the future. This work needs to have its profile raised accordingly.” And they were right. The FDE role attracted high-agency, high-EQ engineers who might otherwise have seen client-facing work as unappreciated. The title gave the work prestige—and Palantir got a hiring moat.</p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;">Some examples</h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Once you start to look, you see title arbitrage everywhere.</p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 auto;"><table class="image-wrapper" width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" data-component-name="Image2ToDOMStatic" style="mso-padding-alt: 1em 0 1.6em;"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td class="content" align="left" width="976" style="text-align: center;"><a class="image-link" target="_blank" href="https://substack.com/redirect/a58cc171-f4c0-4792-9aac-a10deb31f26f?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="position: relative;flex-direction: column;align-items: center;padding: 0;width: auto;height: auto;border: none;text-decoration: none;display: block;margin: 0;"><img class="wide-image" data-attrs="{"src":"https://substack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/images/1c41a5d6-bd90-4f02-ad96-9a62f18b8564_976x550.png","srcNoWatermark":null,"fullscreen":null,"imageSize":null,"height":550,"width":976,"resizeWidth":null,"bytes":null,"alt":null,"title":null,"type":null,"href":null,"belowTheFold":true,"topImage":false,"internalRedirect":null,"isProcessing":false,"align":null,"offset":false}"
